thread.title: Seattle Seahawk Michael Bennett reponds to Martellus and to critics of his penalty
thread.title_full: Seattle Seahawk Michael Bennett reponds to Martellus and to critics of his penalty

author: Bob Condotta
title: Seattle Seahawk Michael Bennett reponds to Martellus and to critics of his penalty
text:
Seattle Seahawk Michael Bennett reponds to Martellus and to critics of his penalty Originally published October 14, 2015 at 2:53 pm Updated October 14, 2015 at 2:58 pm Seahawks defensive lineman Michael Bennett sacks Bengals quarterback Andy Dalton as the Seattle Seahawks take on the Cincinnati Bengals at Paul Brown Stadium in Cincinnati, Ohio Sunday, October 11, 2015. (Bettina Hansen / The Seattle Times) Seattle Seahawk Michael Bennett responded to a jab from his brother and said he saw nothing wrong with his actions that led to a penalty in Sunday's game against the Bengals. 
Seattle Seahawk Michael Bennett had sharp retorts Wednesday for his brother, Martellus, and critics of the personal foul penalty he received Sunday in Cincinnati. 
— First, his brother. Martellus Bennett, a tight end for the Chicago Bears, was asked today about what Michael Bennett said last week after the Seahawks beat Detroit, that he doesn’t like Lions’ QB Matthew Stafford because, well, he’s from Dallas and that’s where JFK was killed (the Bears play the Lions this week). Martellus Bennett responded that he had no issue with Stafford (noting that Stafford “probably” wasn’t even born yet) and that his brother is, well, an “a..hole.” 
Said Michael today when asked about what Martellus said: “Yeah, a rich a..hole.” 
So, there you go. Most Read Stories 
— Next, Michael Bennett received a well-discussed personal foul penalty in Sunday’s game when he repeatedly blocked Cincinnati quarterback Andy Dalton during an interception return by Seattle’s Earl Thomas (you can view it here) . 
The Seahawks received what was in essence a 51-yard penalty, and ended up kicking a field goal on the drive — coach Pete Carroll said Monday the play might have cost Seattle a touchdown. 
Carroll on Monday said Bennett “just lost his mind a little bit.” 
Wednesday, though, Bennett protested that, saying he was simply treating a quarterback the way he would a player at any other position. “I don’t think I was out of control,” he said “I just hit the quarterback. Just because he’s the quarterback it’s a big deal. Carriers get hit all the time and knocked to the ground, but the only time people care — one, he’s the quarterback and he gets paid a lot of money and people just put this zoom-in screen on it so it becomes a big deal.But I can show you tons of plays where offensive linemen are jumping on guys all the time and it’s not a big deal.” Asked a follow-up question about the play, Bennett said: “I hit him, he got back up. I pushed him back down, he got back up. I pushed him down again. What was I supposed to do let him get back up?’’ At that point, teammate Brandon Mebane came over and said with a smile “you should have let him back up, Mike.” Bob Condotta : 206-515-5699 or bcondotta@seattletimes.com ; on Twitter: @bobcondotta . Bob Condotta covers the Seahawks for the Seattle Times. He provides daily coverage of the team throughout the year.
